name: Persecution under Septimius Severus
summary: Emperor Septimius Severus issued an edict in 202 AD prohibiting conversion to Judaism or Christianity. This led to widespread persecution, particularly in North Africa and Egypt. The most famous martyrs of this period were Perpetua and Felicity in Carthage, whose detailed account of their imprisonment and martyrdom is one of the earliest Christian texts written by a woman.

name: Decian Persecution
summary: The Decian persecution (250-251 AD) was the first empire-wide, systematic persecution of Christians in the Roman Empire. Emperor Decius issued an edict requiring all citizens to perform a sacrifice to the Roman gods and obtain a certificate (libellus) proving their compliance. Many Christians refused and were martyred, while others lapsed and later sought readmission to the Church, leading to debates about penance and reconciliation.

name: Novatian Schism
summary: The Novatian Schism began in 251 AD when Novatian, a Roman presbyter, was consecrated as an antipope in opposition to Pope Cornelius. Novatian and his followers, known as Novatianists, held that those who had lapsed during persecution could not be readmitted to the Church, even after penance. The schism lasted for several centuries and was eventually condemned by the Church.

name: Valerian Persecution
summary: The Valerian persecution (257-260 AD) was a systematic persecution of Christians under Emperor Valerian. Initially targeting clergy and church property, it later extended to all Christians. Notable martyrs included Pope Sixtus II, St. Lawrence, and St. Cyprian of Carthage. The persecution ended when Valerian was captured by the Persians in 260 AD.
